qas.question: What is the struggle that Darwin describes about population likened to?
Within what frame of reference does Darwin use the phrase "Struggle for Existence?"
What was Charles Lyell's perception of what organisms are exposed to in their struggle for survival?

answers.text: all organisms are exposed to severe competition

qas.question: When is competition strongest in the natural world?

answers.text: competition is most severe between closely related forms

qas.question: Why is competition so fierce between related species?

answers.text: fill nearly the same place in the economy of nature".

context: He notes that both A. P. de Candolle and Charles Lyell had stated that <a2_0>all organisms are exposed to severe competition<a2_0/>. Darwin emphasizes that he used the phrase "struggle for existence" in <a1_0>"a large and metaphorical sense<a1_0/>, including dependence of one being on another"; he gives examples ranging from plants struggling against drought to plants competing for birds to eat their fruit and disseminate their seeds. He describes the struggle resulting from population growth: "It is the <a0_0>doctrine of Malthus<a0_0/> applied with manifold force to the whole animal and vegetable kingdoms." He discusses checks to such increase including complex ecological interdependencies, and notes that <a3_0>competition is most severe between closely related forms<a3_0/> "which <a4_0>fill nearly the same place in the economy of nature".
